citation.article-title: Emended description of the genus Polynucleobacter and the species Polynucleobacter necessarius and proposal of two subspecies, P. necessarius subsp. necessarius subsp. nov. and P. necessarius subsp. asymbioticus subsp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Polynucleobacter necessarius subsp. necessarius subsp. nov.
Polynucleobacter necessarius subsp. necessarius (nec.es.sa′ri.us. L. masc. adj. necessarius indispensable, necessary).
Possesses the characteristics previously described by Heckmann & Schmidt (1987) for the species Polynucleobacter necessarius.
Contains Polynucleobacter necessarius strains obligately living as endosymbionts in cells of the ciliates E. aediculatus and E. harpa.

Includes Polynucleobacter necessarius reference material contained in the E. aediculatus ‘stock 15’ culture (=E24=ATCC 30859) (Heckmann & Schmidt, 1987) and the endosymbiontic strain STIR1 contained in the E. aediculatus STIR1 culture (Petroni et al., 2002; Vannini et al., 2007), as well as three strains detected in three cultures of the brackish water ciliate E. harpa (Vannini et al., 2005, 2007).

Currently, it is assumed that Polynucleobacter necessarius symbionts of different Euplotes species descended from a single endosymbiosis event; however, all phylogenetic analyses so far performed (Fig. 1) leave the possibility open of a polyphyletic origin by ancestry of endosymbionts of different Euplotes species from different free-living Polynucleobacter necessarius strains.
Strains usually have elongated cells with cell lengths >2.5 μm, and usually possess multiple nucleoid-like structures.
Genome size ranges from 1.5 to 1.8 Mbp.
All attempts to cultivate the obligate endosymbionts outside of their host cells have failed so far; therefore the subspecies lacks a type strain cultivated as a pure culture.

Thus the type of Polynucleobacter necessarius is a description based on endosymbionts in the culture ‘stock 15’ of the ciliate E. aediculatus (Heckmann & Schmidt, 1987) deposited at the ATCC (as E. aediculatus E24, =ATCC 30859).
